Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medicinal Commentary on *Dryopteris ludoviciana* by Kara deGroote
Comment: Lord says this can was used to cure an infectious disease, which could have been *Lues Venerea* (syphilis) or another disease that is more than a 'malignant scurvy', but he is not sure which. There doesn’t seem to be any solid evidence or discussion on the topic of this plant having any ability to cure any sort of infectious disease or much else in direction of medicinal properties. See [http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/lues+venerea](http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/lues+venerea).

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medicinal Commentary on *Gentiana saponaria* by Kara deGroote
Comment: Lord says this plant was one of the first Gentians in Culppers Description in his English Physician. Gentians are mountainous plants, which are used to produce tonic when extracted from the roots. Today _Gentiana saponaria_ is still used as a tonic, but is also used for a number of other things including liver complaints, indigestion, gastric infections, and anorexia (pfaf). There is little research on the medicinal effects of this species of the _Gentiana_ genus, and I found nothing about this plant related to the treatment of syphilis. See [http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Gentiana+saponaria](http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Gentiana+saponaria)

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Ctenium aromaticum* (Walter) Wood
Comment: Lord says it draws rheum (water-like discharge that is produced by the mucuous membranes of the eyes and nose) from the head, and can therefore cure toothaches caused by this. He also says that when he combines laxatives ('purges') with this plant to treat tissue swelling ('dropsy'), it is a powerful diuretic ('provokes urine'). While Lord claims this plant was also useful in removing excess water in the body, it seems today that this plant’s most effective medical use is as a mild numbing agent for the mouth, and hence the common name, toothache grass (roundstoneseed; treasure coast native; Gamboa-Leon R, Chilton WS 2000. 'Isobutylamide numbing agents of toothache grass, *ctenium aromaticum*.' *Biochem Syst Ecol* 28(10):1019. Today the common name is toothache grass because it numbs the mouth when chewed.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Ageratina aromatica* (L.) Spach
Comment: Lord says it has 'virtue against the biting of the rattle-snake'. This plant contains a chemical that is toxic to cattle and can cause 'milk sickness' in humans ingesting the milk of cattle eating this plant. In the Midwest, this killed many settlers and was responsible for the death of Abraham Lincoln’s mother. Clewell AF and Wooten JW. 1971. 'A revision of *ageratina* (*compositae: Eupatorieae*) from eastern north america.' *Brittonia* 23(2):123-43. For humans, however, this plant is said to be an antispasmodic, diaphoretic, diuretic, and expectorant, but there is no substantial research to prove these are valid uses (practicalplants). The plant is antispasmodic, diaphoretic, diuretic and expectorant. It is used in the treatment of inflammation and irritability of the bladder, ague, pulmonary diseases, stomach complaints and nervous diseases. [http://practicalplants.org/wiki/Ageratina_aromatica](http://practicalplants.org/wiki/Ageratina_aromatica).

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Eupatorium rotundifolium* (L.)
Comment: Lord says this species is used for fevers and an admirable antidote against rattle snake bites. I found no uses of that sort, but a species of the same genus, 'Eupatorium perfoliatum' supposedly helps with the following: constipation, inducing vomiting, retaining fluid, aching muscles, reducing inflammation, and stimulating the immune system.(webmd). *Eupatorium rotundifolium* does, however, 'possess growth inhibitory activity', which may be useful in the treatment of tumors. Kelsey JE. 1969. *Structural Studies on Tumor Inhibitory Sesquiterpene Lactones.* Wisconsin: The University of Wisconsin - Madison; Kupchan SM, Kelsey JE, Muruyama M, Cassady JM, Hemingway JC, Knox JR. 1969. 'Tumor inhibitors. XLI. structural elucidation of tumor inhibitory sesquiterpene lactones from eupatorium rotundifolium.' *J Org Chem* 34(12):3876; [http://www.herbs2000.com/herbs/herbs_boneset.htm](http://www.herbs2000.com/herbs/herbs_boneset.htm); [http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-594-BONESET.aspx?activeIngredientId=594&activeIngredientName=BONESET](http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-594-BONESET.aspx?activeIngredientId=594&activeIngredientName=BONESET).

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Helianthus strumosus* (L.)
Comment: A surgeon showed this plant to Lord and understood that many people call this plant 'all-heal'. This root was used by Native Americans to treat worms. When made into tea, this plant is used to alleviate lung problems. Though it is not supported by substantial evidence,  'A decoction of the roots has been used to get rid of worms in both adults and children. An infusion of the roots has been used in the treatment of lung problems'. [http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Helianthus+strumosus](http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Helianthus+strumosus).

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Verbena carnea* (Medik.) Moldenke
Comment: Lord said this plant seemed to be a Sideritis or Ironwort plant, which have traditionally been used as herbal teas as a means of curing respiratory diseases and gastrointestinal discomfort, inflammation, and rheumatic disordrers. These types of plants have 'been used in traditional medicine in the treatment of gastrointestinal complaints, Inflammation, and rheumatic disorders.'  They have alos been proven to have strong anti-inflammatory effects and gastroprotective activities as well as cytotoxicity. *Verbena carnea*, however, is not of the *Sideritis* genus, but no research has been done to see if this plant could have similar medicinal effects. [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22274814](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22274814); [http://www.fragrantica.com/news/MOUNTAIN-TEA-Sideritis-The-Humble-3706.html](http://www.fragrantica.com/news/MOUNTAIN-TEA-Sideritis-The-Humble-3706.html); [http://herbs-treatandtaste.blogspot.com/2012/07/ironwort-mountain-tea-plant-scientific.html](http://herbs-treatandtaste.blogspot.com/2012/07/ironwort-mountain-tea-plant-scientific.html).

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Thalictrum macrostylum* Small & Heller
Comment: Lord says this plant could be a *Thalictrum* or Bastard Rhubarb. Rhubarbs were known to possess a number of medicinal uses including those as an astringent, tonic, stomachic (digestion stimulant), and aperient (mild purgative). This plant is, however, a *Thalictrum* species, sometimes referred to as 'Poor Man’s Rhubarb' in Europe for having similar effects as Rhubarb at higher doses. None of the American species of *Thalictrum* have been analyzed for these types of effects. While no medicinal effects have been studied for this particular species of *Thalictrum*, *Thalictrum minus* has been found to have many components of antioxidants (Karyagina, Bairamashvili, Gukasova 2011). Alkaloids of various species of *Thalictrum* have been extracted, exemplifying significant antibacterial properties, which researchers say deem the plant acceptable for use in treating microbrial infections (as it’s used in Kenya) (Mayeku PW et al. 2013). Research on species of the Thalictrum genus is continuously growing, making *Thalictrum macrostylum* an interesting species for further research.  [http://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/r/rhubar14.html](http://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/r/rhubar14.html) [http://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/dmna/thalictrum-dioi.html](http://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/dmna/thalictrum-dioi.html); Karyagina T.B., Bairamashvili D.I., Gukasova E.A. 2011. 'Antioxidant activity of extracts from *Thalictrum minus* suspension culture.' *Russian Journal of Plant Physiology a Comprehensive Russian Journal on Modern Phytophysiology* 58(4):715-20.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Pycanthemum flexuosum* (Walter) BSP
Comment: Lord says this plant is called Wild Hysssop (known today as *Verbena hastata* or Blue Vervain), but smells like Calamint. Calamint is a plant used today to alleviate chest congestion and respiratory illness associated with colds and fevers in addition to promoting sweating. Blue vervain is known to have a number of medicinal benefits, used in the treatments of many ailments such as asthma,whooping cough, angina, depression, itching, etc. *Pycanthemum flexuosum* has actually been said to act as an analgesic (pain reliever), diaphoretic (perspiration stimulant), febrifuge (fever reducer), and a stomachic (digestion stimulant) (pfaf). There has not yet been any substantial research to support these claims.  [http://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Pycnanthemum+flexuosuma](http://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Pycnanthemum+flexuosuma); [http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-613-CALAMINT.aspx?activeIngredientId=613&activeIngredientName=CALAMINT](http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-613-CALAMINT.aspx?activeIngredientId=613&activeIngredientName=CALAMINT); [http://healingherbinfo.com/index.php/herbs/herb/wild_hyssop1](http://healingherbinfo.com/index.php/herbs/herb/wild_hyssop1); [http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-88-VERBENA.aspx?activeIngredientId=88&activeIngredientName=VERBENA](http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-88-VERBENA.aspx?activeIngredientId=88&activeIngredientName=VERBENA)

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Pycanthemum flexuosum* (Walter) BSP
Comment: Lord mistakes this plant again for Wild Hyssop or, as it’s more commonly known today, Blue Vervain. This plant is said to act as an analgesic (pain reliever), diaphoretic (perspiration stimulant), febrifuge (fever reducer), and a stomachic (digestion stimulant) although none of these claims are backed up by research (pfaf). What research has shown is that eritrichin, a compound of this plant has an inhibitory effect on hyaluronidase (which breaks down hyaluronic acid) (Murata et al. 2014). Hyaluronic acid has both medical advantages and disadvantages including anti-aging effects and enabling metastasis of tumors, making the ability to inhibit hyaluronidase of interest.  [http://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Pycnanthemum+flexuosum](http://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Pycnanthemum+flexuosum); [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyaluronic_acid#cite_note-51](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyaluronic_acid#cite_note-51); [http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-1062-HYALURONIC%20ACID.aspx?activeIngredientId=1062&activeIngredientName=HYALURONIC%20ACID](http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-1062-HYALURONIC%20ACID.aspx?activeIngredientId=1062&activeIngredientName=HYALURONIC%20ACID); [https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/62/6/62_c14-00123/_article](https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/62/6/62_c14-00123/_article); [https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/62/6/62_c14-00123/_html#ack](https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/62/6/62_c14-00123/_html#ack).

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Scutellaria integrifolia* L.
Comment: Lord thought this plant was a Bugle or *Ajuga reptans*, which are known to possess some abilitites to stem bleeding. Additionally, bugles are thought to help with coughs, hallucinations from excessive alcohol intake, liver disorders, and ulcers. While *Scutellaria integrifolia* may not be a Bugle plant, extracts of the plant are found to have strong anticancer activity.  Parajuli P, Joshee N, Rimando AM, Mittal S, Yadav AK. 2009. 'In vitro antitumor mechanisms of various scutellaria extracts and constituent flavonoids.' *Planta Med* 75(1):41-8; [http://www.herbs2000.com/herbs/herbs_bugle.htm](http://www.herbs2000.com/herbs/herbs_bugle.htm)

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Aureolaria flava* (L.) Farwell
Comment: Lord thought this to be a sort of Madder (a plant most commonly used as a red dye) or Woodroof (known today as Sweet Woodruff). Though Woodroof was used largely in the Middle Ages for healing wounds, as a stomachic, and to remove 'biliary obstructions from the liver' Lord was mistaken in his assumption that this plant could be a Woodroof. *Auteolaria flava*  does contain iridoid glycosides (Belofsky et al. 1989). Different variants of these compounds are known to have positive health properties such as: neurprotection, anti-cancer and anti-tumor, antiaging, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antibacterial, liver protection, antiviral, cardiovascular protectivion, blood sugar maintenance, artery protection, and antiallergic potential (iridoids). The specific iridoids found in *Aureolaria flava* have not yet been extensively researched to determine their potential medical benefits.  [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/355682/madder](http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/355682/madder); [https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/w/wooswe31.html](https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/w/wooswe31.html); [http://www.iridoids.co.uk/benefit.html](http://www.iridoids.co.uk/benefit.html); Belofsky G, Bowers MD, Janzen S, Stermitz F. 1989. 'Iridoid glycosides of aureolaria flava and their sequestration by euphydryas phaeton butterflies.' *Phytochemistry* 28(6):1601-4.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Trichostema setaceum* Houttuyn
Comment: Lord says this plant smells like Calamint, a plant used today to alleviate chest congestion and respiratory illness associated with colds and fevers in addition to promoting perspiration. There is no evidence or folklore to suggest that *Trichostema setaceum* has medicinal benefits like Calamint or any other sort of medicinal benefit.  [http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-613-CALAMINT.aspx?activeIngredientId=613&activeIngredientName=CALAMINT](http://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-613-CALAMINT.aspx?activeIngredientId=613&activeIngredientName=CALAMINT)

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Oenothera laciniata* Hill
Comment: Lord describes this plant as 'our ordinary scabious'. Using the word 'scabious' as it means in Middle English, Lord likely meant that the plant was used to cure skin disease.  As it turns out, plants of the *Oenothera* genus have a number of medical activities such as: antioxidant, cytotoxic, antibacterial, antiviral, anti-inflammatory, antihyperlipidaemic, thrombolytic and antidiarrhoea (Singh, Kaur, and Sharma 2012). *Oenothera laciniata* in particular has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties (for topical application) (Singh, Kaur, and Sharma 2012; Yoon WJ et al. 2009). In this case, it seems this plant does indeed help with skin conditions as Lord said.  [http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/scabious](http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/scabious); [http://www.jcimjournal.com/jim/FullText2.aspx?articleID=jcim20120701#FullText](http://www.jcimjournal.com/jim/FullText2.aspx?articleID=jcim20120701#FullText); Singh, S. 'An updated review on the Oenothera genus.' *Journal of Chinese Integrative Medicine*, 10, 717-725. Retrieved July 10, 2014, from [http://www.jcimjournal.com/jim/FullText2.aspx?articleID=jcim20120701](http://www.jcimjournal.com/jim/FullText2.aspx?articleID=jcim20120701); Yoon WJ, Ham YM, Yoo BS, Moon JY, Koh J, Hyun CG. 2009. Oenothera laciniata inhibits lipopolysaccharide induced production of nitric oxide, prostaglandin E2, and proinflammatory cytokines in RAW264.7 macrophages. J BIOSCI BIOENG 107(4):429-38.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Nuttallanthus Canadensis* (L.) D. A. Sutton
Comment: Not medically relevant. Lord says it grows in the manner of crosswort. The only significance of that plant is that it contains a red dye sometimes used in medicines.  [http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Crosswort](http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Crosswort)

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Sabatia campanulata* (L.) Torrey
Comment: Lord mistook this plant to be a red Centaury. The actual plant he found appears not to have any known medical uses or folklore on the subject.  [https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/c/centau46.html](https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/c/centau46.html)

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Rhexia mariana* L.
Comment: Again Lord describes this as a rough tea and I am not sure what this means and cannot find any definitions that make sense of it. I cannot find any folklore or research to suggest this plant has any medicinal benefits.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Rhexia nashii* Small
Comment: Lord says this looks and tastes the same as *Rhexia alifanus*, the plant which children called sugar-grass and adults deers-grass. There is no folklore or research to suggest it has any medical applications.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Rhexia petiolata* Walter
Comment: Lord says this is the smalled leaved sugar-grass. Still, there is no folklore or research to suggest the plant has any medicinal applications.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Aesculus pavia* L.
Comment: Lord says this plant was put in the bottom of a basket and shaken about in ponds of standing water. In effect, the fish would 'turn up their bellies as if they were dead, when yet they are taken & eaten without harm.' It seems that this was indeed a legitimate use of this plant by hunting tribes. Other than being used to kill fish, this plant is said to have some medicinal uses as well including: The same saponin compounds that kill the fish do not effect humans as much especially when not directly ingested. These saponins, however, have cytotoxic effects, which researchers believe may help in treating cancer (Sun et al. 2011; Zhang and Li 2007).  [http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Aesculus+pavia](http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Aesculus+pavia); Sun Z, Wan A, Zhang R, Zhang M, Wu Y. 2011. 'Bioactive saponins from the fruits of *aesculus pavia L.*' [electronic resource]. *Fitoterapia* 82(7):1106-9; Zhang Z and Li S. 2007. Cytotoxic triterpenoid saponins from the fruits of aesculus pavia L [electronic resource]. Phytochemistry 68(15):2075-86.

Author: K. DeGroote
Label: Medical Commentary on *Ilex ambigua* (Michaux) Torrey
Comment: Lord says that an Indian told him this plant was useful in treating headaches caused by malaria-like illnesses.  I found no folklore or research done to suggest this plant, the Carolina holly, has medicinal uses.
